body.p: The Board was persuaded by the arguments made by some stakeholders that applying prudence (defined as the exercise of caution when making judgements under conditions of uncertainty) can help to achieve neutrality in applying accounting policies. Thus, ‘cautious prudence’ (see paragraphÂ BC2.37(a)) can help to achieve a faithful representation of assets, liabilities, equity, income and expenses. Setting out that message clearly is expected to:

li.p: help preparers, auditors and regulators to counter a natural bias that management may have towards optimism; for example, the message underlines the need to exercise care in selecting the inputs used in estimating a measure that cannot be observed directly; and
help the Board to develop rigorous Standards that would reduce the risk of management bias in applying the reporting entity’s accounting policies.
